results.title: Sons of Namatjira (A)
results.creator_credit: Curtis Levy and Australian Institute of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Studies
results.brief_description: Keith Namatjira and his relatives paint in the style of his father, Albert and live in an artist’s camp set up by his father on the outskirts of Alice Springs. Highlights problems which the Namatjiras and Aborigines in general have to confront in their relationship with the world outside the community.

results.title: Three horsemen: three generations of Aboriginal stockmen (A)
results.creator_credit: Judith MacDougall, David MacDougall and Australian Institute of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Studies
results.brief_description: Earlier this century, Aboriginal stockmen were the backbone of the cattle industry throughout much of Australia. Bob Massey Pootchemunka has spent most of his life as a stockman and drover, and now over 75, his ambition is to see an all-Aboriginal cattle station operating at Ti-Tree, where he and his relatives recently returned to live on their traditional clan land. Bob’s dream includes his nephew Eric, an experienced stockman as the station manager, and Eric’s son, Ian, as a future stockman. “Three Horsemen” is about the persistence of ideals from an important phase in Aboriginal history, and the formidable difficulties three people face in fulfilling them.

results.title: London
results.creator_credit: David McKenzie and Associated Television International
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Travel tips”.
How do I get around in a city like London? What type of coat should I pack? What is the best time to see the Changing of the Guard at Buckingham Palace? Where’s an old English pub? Where should I go outside of London? These are just some of the questions travel expert Laura McKenzie answers in this fascinating tour of London. Included are day trips to Windsor Castle, Blenheim Palace, Stratford-upon-Avon, Ragley Hall and Warwick Castle.

results.title: Bermuda, Bahama, Jamaica
results.creator_credit: Peter Teneyck and Video Trip Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Rand McNally video visit trips”.
Tricia Springer takes you on a tour of three exotic ports of call in the Caribbean. Behind the picture postcard beauty of Bermuda is an island filled with activity, and British tradition. Turquoise waters and natural beauty await you in the Bahamas, which has a vital night life of discos, casinos and Las Vegas style shows. Jamaica is truly West Indian and is permeated by the calypso and reggae beats. Included are bonus tips on getting there, accommodation, food, special events, clothing and climate.

results.title: Return to the dreaming (A)
results.creator_credit: Cecil Holmes, Robert Raymond and Opus Films
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Australian ark”.
Yirrawala, the great Aboriginal painter, takes his two sons who have grown up in the white man’s world back into Arnhem Land in an attempt to find the sacred caves and art galleries of his tribe. During the journey Yirrawala makes a bark painting in the traditional way and we see cave paintings never before recorded.

results.title: 14's good, 18's better
results.creator_credit: Gillian Armstrong, Timothy Read, Hilary Linstead, Film Australia, M and L and Big Picture
results.brief_description: A longitudinal study of three Adelaide girls, now 18, intercut with footage from “Smokes and lollies”, shot when they were 14. Their previous expectations have been altered by the experiences of marriage, parenthood, employment, low incomes and insecurity. However, they remain optimistic, with their humour intact. (Awards: Winner, Best Australian Educational Short Film, Australian Teachers of Media (ATOM) Awards, 1982)
results.creator_credit_for_label: Gillian Armstrong, Timothy Read, Hilary Linstead, Film Australia, M and L and Big Picture

results.title: Madarrpa funeral at Gurka'wuy
results.brief_description: In the small Aboriginal community of Gurka’wuy, 170 kms. south of Yirrkala, a baby dies. Subtitled “a way of coping with death in north-east Arnhem Land through ties of clan, religion and land”, this film, photographed by Dean Semler, depicts the three day long preparations for the funeral, and the funeral itself. The ceremonies, dances, songs and paintings are described in detail, as the child is symbolically returned to its clan lands further south.

results.title: Photographers of Australia: Dupain, Sievers, Moore
results.creator_credit: Gregory Read, Wolfgang Knochell and Film Australia
results.brief_description: Since the arrival of the camera in Australia in the mid 19th Century, it has recorded the nation’s life. This is the story of some of the most enduring images of the Australian experience and the three men who made them - Max Dupain, Wolfgang Sievers and David Moore. Relive the history of Australia, from the 1930s to the present day through the lenses of these renowned photographers.

results.title: Bali: A Window on Paradise
results.creator_credit: Richard Yerxa, Michael Heumann and Sonoma Video Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Video visits”.
A comprehensive tour of the beautiful Indonesian island of Bali - its slumbering volcanoes, mountain lakes, lush green rice paddies and intricate temples. Bali, despite its dependence on tourism, still retains its vital four thousand year old culture. The video takes us to Lake Bratan; Ubud, the country’s cultural centre; Mas, famous for its carved wood masks; the port of Singaraja and the beaches of Sanur.

results.title: Don't shoot the writer
results.brief_description: An excellent documentary on the evolution of the Australian film and television industry. By interviewing screenwriters such as David Williamson, Eleanor Whitcombe (My Brilliant Career) and Roger Simpson (Sword of Honour) we are given an insight into the struggles in the late 60’s and 70’s to develop an Australian film culture; on the formation of the Australian Writers Guild to help encourage writing for the screen; and the struggle to see their visions realised on television and the cinema.
